ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Traumatic Tympanic Membrane Perforation (Left)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: History of foreign body (beetle) trauma, otoscopic confirmation of perforation, conductive hearing loss component, and inability to obtain tympanometric seal.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess the degree, configuration, and type of hearing loss resulting from the trauma.
To evaluate speech reception thresholds and word recognition abilities to determine functional impact.
To assess middle ear status and confirm the presence of perforation via seal integrity.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The evaluation confirms a traumatic left tympanic membrane perforation. Audiometry reveals a mixed hearing loss in the left ear with significant air-bone gaps, while the right ear is essentially normal. Tympanometry in the left ear could not be completed due to the inability to maintain a seal, consistent with the perforation.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear: Normal to slight sensorineural hearing loss. Left ear: Mild sloping to moderately severe mixed hearing loss (250-2000 Hz), rising to slight/mild mixed loss (3000-8000 Hz); air-bone gaps present.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRT: Right 15 dB HL (normal), Left 40 dB HL (mild loss). WRS: 100% bilaterally at suprathreshold levels.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear: Normal (Type A). Left ear: Could not maintain a seal due to perforation.

proposed_items: Referral to otolaryngology for surgical repair (tympanoplasty)
counseling_actions: Explain the mixed nature of the hearing loss (conductive component from perforation vs. sensorineural component)
Discuss the impact of perforation on hearing clarity versus volume
Review surgical repair options (tympanoplasty) given the failure of the paper patch

escalation.rationale_short: Surgical repair (tympanoplasty) is indicated for the persistent traumatic perforation after failed paper patch myringoplasty.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor tympanic membrane healing and assess post-surgical hearing thresholds.

expected_outcome: At 3 weeks post-surgery, the tympanic membrane was healing well; the patient reported hearing was muffled but improved, with mild persistent imbalance.
At 3 months post-surgery, the patient reported further improvement in hearing despite persistent tinnitus.

Post-operative Pure-tone audiometry (3 months): Right ear thresholds remained stable; Left ear thresholds improved by 20 dB HL at 500 and 1,000 Hz and by 25 dB HL at 250 and 2,000 Hz, resulting in normal hearing sloping to a slight to mild mixed loss.

Post-operative Speech audiometry (3 months): SRTs revealed normal ability in the right ear (15 dB HL) and a mild loss in the left ear (30 dB HL); WRS remained normal bilaterally (Right 96%, Left 92%).
Tympanometry was not performed at the 3-month follow-up due to recent otosurgery.
The patient declined hearing aids or assistive technology but may attend a tinnitus management class.
